text:
My kids love this game! I like it too, as it is easy to play, doesn't take long, allows for everyone to join in. Sometimes the various rules can be confusing for the younger kids to remember, but most of us know the rules by now and we only have occasional disagreements as to what is allowed. Adults and kids play and amazingly the adults don't automatically win. My kids can win just as easily.
basically the winner is the first person who collects three complete sets of properties. Players steal, trade and win properties from other players. Really a fun game we all enjoy.

title: 10/10 Fun and Fast Game
text:
We love love LOVE this game. It's not like Monopoly at all, it only take 5-15 minutes to play and we play it so often that we needed to replace our deck. I bought a new deck from Walmart and I was disappointed that they changed the style of the cards and they were impossible to read -terribly designed. I ended up giving that deck to someone else and bought these instead and it's way better.

I saw some complaints that there were cards missing so I checked and there was one card missing: 1$. I took one from my old deck and it's fine. We could have played without it - the original might have been missing one too and I'd never have known.

This game is super family-friendly, fast, and fun!
10/10 recommend!

title: I'm pretty shocked at how much we ended up liking this ...
text: I'm pretty shocked at how much we ended up liking this game. It's a combination of rummy and monopoly and games have all been less than 15 minutes for us. Basically, you are trying to lay down three complete sets of properties before the other players. There are cards they can play that allow them to steal one or more of your properties, force you to pay them, etc. which makes it a little hard. A hand limit of 7 cards and a play limit of 3 cards per turn means that you can't hold on to all of your properties and then play them at once. The mechanics make it easier for someone who is way behind to catch up and win the game or vice versa. Very fun, fast, easy to learn, and great all around card game when you don't have the time for the board game.

title: Fun, Strategic Game That You Can Play Quickly and Even Teach Young Children
text:
This is a great game that I've played a dozen times with friends and family.

The rules are simple - draw 2 cards a turn, play up to 3 cards. First to get 3 sets wins the game.

When we played with 3-4 players it was a little more strategy. 2 players I would not recommend as if one player takes the lead the game is usually pretty much over. I would say 4-6+ players makes for a lot more frenetic game where people try to keep the "top" player down and is probably the best mix.

We bought two decks to play with larger groups. The cards are good quality and should last. There are some areas in the rules where there is ambiguity but for a fun game that you can play in 10-20 minutes you can't go wrong.

We've played with young children and they catch on pretty quickly, though perhaps they don't hold their "powerful" cards and play them more quickly than adults would. There is enough luck and chance though that they still have the opportunity to win.

So if you are a serious board/card gamer who doesn't like elements of luck you may not like this game. I would say this game is probably about 50/50 - some games if the other person is lucky, there is just nothing you can do, but that's ok - in 10 minutes you can play the next game.

title: Fun - Hint For First Time
text: The quality of the cards and packaging was fine. The game takes a time or two to figure out (HINT: Play once by yourself with a fake player and you'll get it without as much confusion). Seems like a fun little portable and far shorter version of Monopoly if you have the patience to learn how it works - not as obvious as using a board but the game is probably more fun for folks who think the real game is tediously long. Still need some space to lay down the cards while playing.

title: Amazing game - Very easy to play and teach
text:
I've always said if Monopoly ruins friendships, this will test them.

A ton of fun, very easy to pick up and teach a great "gateway" game if you want to introduce people into deck building games (Sushi Go, Love Letter are also great).

It does play in 15 minutes once you've played it for a number of hands and know what you are doing.

Quick tip - 2 players play till 4 or 5 Monopoly's.

It is WELL worth the $4-$6 you will play. I've played it hundreds of times of the years, bought it for friends and family. There is a reason that it has such good reviews.

title: MUST BUY!!!!!!!!!!
text:
Ok so let me get started on this freaken game!
This game is totally fun and it is not your average monopoly game. I played this deal card game with my brother everyday and played for at least an hour. Mind that we are both competitive, we would play for that time period. At first, the rules for the game seem complicated and seemingly playing the game may be hard. But as you play more and more, it gets pretty easy to play and know all the run down.
There are time where some action cards used in games are debatable and is not on the list on the rules SO YOU LOOK ONLINE FOR FURTHER RULES. I remember playing a deal breaker and my brother used a just say no card, but I used a just say no card on that just say no card. Confusing,huh? The rules says that you can use a just say card on an action card, but it doesn't specifically said on another same card. So I went to look online, and lord behold, my last just say card works and I beat him out of his game.
If you looking for a quick fun card game, BUY IT. Don't hesitated of buying it, BUY IT and play it for yourself.

title: Short, sweet, unique, familiar game for all!
text: To start off I am a huge board game and card game fan. I have over 100 games in my collection that get played regularly at game night. Though monopoly is a game for not everyone me and my sister love it and play regularly and have over 10 different versions. Having said that we were not really interested in this because it seemed potentially boring. BUT..one day I‚Äôm shopping for a gift for a friend who is a regular in my game night group and I typically like to gift a fun new game. I was having a hard time finding one I liked, but behold a stranger was eavesdropping and gifted me the gift of knowledge. She told me about this game. A game she gifts to everyone. And so what did I do?? Go on amazon and order one so I can test it out before gifting it to see if it was fun. It was. I went to visit my parents (who HATE monopoly) and told them they have to try this new game out, WE HAD SO MUCH FUN. It is extremely easy to learn despite the instructions seeming a little overwhelming (according to my mom). Would recommend for everyone!! It really is just a perfect short and sweet card game and a VERY unique but familiar version of the game I love.

title: Great family game! Fast paced, simple, interesting!
text: This is a fantastic game - it's one of the few that's really fun regardless of whether you're playing with 2 people, 3 people, or 5 people. It continues to be interesting and fast paced regardless of the number of players (which isn't the case for most card games, which are optimized for a particular number of players). The fact that game play is so fast (it takes about 10 minutes with two players, 20 with 5) makes the game super addictive. This also makes it great for killing awkward chunks of time in the middle of your day/evening (20-30 mins).

title: It's Monopoly, but Fun
text:
Do you have any childhood memories with Monopoly? Of course you do. Are any of them particularly good memories? Didn't think so.
If you answered yes to the first question and no to the second, then you need Monopoly Deal in your life.
This might be the greatest value I've ever gotten out of five dollars spent on a game. This treasure is a serious steal. It's Monopoly, but fun.

I only have one complaint, since the game is such a bargain price, the cards are a little cheap. I always handle them with a lot of care because I can tell they'll easily warp under strenuous use. I would honestly pay an extra ten bucks to have this fantastic game reprinted with higher quality cards, like the kind of cards Rio Grande uses to print their Dominion decks on.
This game is of a disparagingly higher quality than the cards it's printed on.

title: Our favorite game
text:
This is one of my favorite games
When we play with new people we always caution the the first round will be more of a learning round, but it's really easy to pick up.
You can play with up to five players, which we have done before, but I think it's a little much and I find the center deck depletes pretty quickly. I think four players is the sweet spot. We've also been thinking about adding another deck and seeing how that will play
We recently took an international trip and brought this along to play in the airport while we were waiting around and it was great
As another reviewer mentioned, there are some scenarios that are not explained in the rules - for instance, we weren't sure if a "just say no" card could be played against another "just say no card", to settle it we ended up emailing Hasbro and to our surprise they emailed us back pretty quickly with the answer! (according to Hasbro, you can use a "just so no" card against another")
You can definitely play a round in 15 minutes, but we've had some rounds that have lasted a little longer. Overall it's a really enjoyable game and we spend most of the time laughing while we play

title: Bait and switch
text:
Beware. They will bait you with the belief that you are buying the upgraded version as shown on the picture but they will switch the cheaper version. They claim it is the same game but it is not and the games are not priced the same. I have played both and highly recommend the upgraded (green deck). They sent me the cheaper deck and are requiring me to pay return postage even though they sent the wrong (much less expensive card deck). This is a scam!!!
Note if zero stars were allowed that would be too many.

title: Best Fun Way to Lose friends( bonus: how to damage your relationship too!)
text:
I played this in high school and it was so fun, my third year in college I remembered about the game and went out to look for it. I went to Target,Walmart, CVS, Walgreens NONE OF THEM HAD IT! I finally went to Rite-aid as a last resort and there it was, the last one but it was $10. I bought it and played for weeks and then I thought... wait why don't I try Amazon?!? It was on amazon for $6 but gradually ( more like everyday) the price continued to drop, it kept going down a few cents every time I went back to my cart. Amazon would notify me of the price changes and I waited for a month and it went to $4.99. I bought the item and returned the one I got from Rite-aid.

Off the bat they were more fancy, because the plastic was wrapped in a gold and black foil in plastic compared to Rite-aid which was just plastic (small difference I know but still a pro) the colors also looked more vibrant and so much nicer. Also really fun and addicting game to kill the time with friends!

Tips to win: try to get property from your friends by renting them when they have little $ so they have to give property

Tips for best enjoyment: Get a blue or green set which rents the most, add houses and hotels, then wait til you have a blue/green rent which rents everybody instead of the wild color rent which targets only one. In your hand you should have the blue/green rent card, and two double rents and PLAY THEM, MAKE YOUR FRIENDS(OPPONENTS) SUFFER AND NEVER TRUST YOU EVER AGAIN.

WARNING: Do not do the mentioned above strategy to your boyfriend/girlfriend/wife/husband unless you are ready to console them and make it up to them when you DESTROY their lives and their enjoyment of the game forever. Like seriously.. this is from personal experience, funny for the first few seconds when they have to count all their money and property and hand it to you but then you feel really bad when they start crying. AGAIN DO NOT DO TO LOVED ONES

title: Way better than regular monopoly!
text: I hate monopoly. It lasts forever. Someone always seems to get mad while playing. It lasts forever. And did i mention...the game lasts forever?! Enter monopoly deal! It's quick, easy to learn, no hard feelings, and so much more fun than regular monopoly! We can play a game in a little as 15 minutes and if someone is upset they didn't win, we have plenty of time to play again and let them redeem themselves. There's no counting of the money/properties at the end...just a clear cut winner. Best invention ever. And it's easy enough that my 6 year old can play it! We bought this a few years ago and then lost it. We missed it so much that we finally rebought it again for Christmas. Definitely give it a try!

title: The go-to game in our household
text:
My wife and I have played over 150 games of Monopoly Deal since buying it 3.5 months ago. When your initial investment is just $6, that makes for a fantastic return on investment. After playing it that many times, we still are not tired of it. While we do not play it as often as we did in the early weeks of owning the game, we still enjoy playing.

It would be a great game to play with kids, too.

For us, it's a great way to spend 30-60 minutes together for a casual date night. Since each game only takes about 15 minutes, we typically play best of 3 or best of 5 together.

Pros:

- easy to learn
- game play is fast-paced
- it brings everything that is great about the original Monopoly game, while cutting out a lot of the bad
- every game is different, since the card combinations are endless

Cons:

- there really aren't any major cons
- if I had to name one, it would be that once each player learns the strategy, most of one's success is the result of luck, rather than skill. But that's not a big deal, because this game remains a hoot.

title: DEAL replaced the board game version
text:
This has replaced the full version of the game and it plays in minutes not hours.

The game is a great game of balancing risk of playing cards at the best time with disrupting opponents strategy for your gain.

I have seen some complain about the luck in this game...that you could lose a game because you don't get the right cards. This is true sometimes, but it can be nearly eliminated by strategically playing your cards with the right amount of balance. For example, it is helpful to not play property cards until you have money to protect it and a strategy for what you and competition are doing. If your opponent plays a park place and you have the matching card to complete the set it doesn't make sense to play that until you can steal or complete the whole set on one turn.

Fun game for adults to play with kids too.

title: Good Idea, Rules Need Improvements
text:
This is a good alternative to Uno. It is quick to learn and play, requires a casual level of thought, and is entertaining. Where it falls down is in the rules. The board game it's based on is about finance. You invest in properties to make more money, to buy more properties, to make more money, etc. Along the way, you also use your money to pay debts (rent, mostly).

In the card game, you never have to buy properties. Money is only used to pay debts. If you are out of money, you have to use your properties to pay your debts. This means money is used solely to defend against losing your properties, which you get by drawing them at random, or taking them from other players is forced swaps. Thus, the rules say you win by acquiring three complete sets of properties. The amount of money you have is not considered.

So, it's a fun game. But the victory conditions make no sense, and the spend-money-to-make-money theme of the board game isn't there. I think a card game based on Monopoly is a great idea. The rules of this one, however, just don't reach the idea's potential.

title: Way better than the classic board game!
text:
My husband is a Monopoly fan from 60 years ago. When he saw this deck of cards he didn't give it much chance. It took days for him to agree to sit down and try it......But once I beat him two games in a row....in less than 30 minutes.... he was hooked!
This game has all the excitement and dirty tricks that makes the classic board game seem like child's play. Cards allowing you to take a property or to even take a whole set of properties from your opponent makes it exciting and the final winner less predictable.
Since it is a card game there are no tiny parts or fake money to handle...so we can play it anywhere....any time.

title: Don't play this if you wanna stay married
text:
If you wanna stay married, don't play this game with your spouse. You might think you are winning and then one turn later, your hand is dog excrement. And who's to blame but your significant other, whose smug smile slips out an insincere, "I'm sorry."

So, you get another turn, and you make some headway, climbing out of debt and back on the board. And suddenly she has three sets of properties and in an instant your hope is swept up by the wind and blown down a storm drain. You lose. You lose like always, because you NEVER win.

You pretend to be a good sport and you force a smile on the surface while you over-annunciate "Good job", unable to look her in the eyes‚Äìthat stare! It burns a whole right through you and sees all your disgusting weaknesses and decaying worth. Why is she staring at me?! STOP LOOKING AT ME!

Great card game though. Much better than the board game, in my opinion.

title: Quickly learned, but strategic!
text:
My gaming friends and I played this for the first time. We had so much fun playing it that this is permanently finding a place in our travel gaming box. Yes, we keep a little box full of small games in the car, right next to the jumper cables. In case of emergency gaming!

We are not a family board game group. There are plenty of reviews here for that crowd. We are gamers. This group has played Monopoly and Catan, sure, but we are more likely to get out Runebound (second and third edition each get a turn), Descent, or one of the D&D tile games like Castle Ravenloft. That is, we play those games when we aren't playing the Dragon Age RPG from Green Ronin or D&D 5th edition or building Shadowrun characters that we never get around to actually playing. :D

This same group responded excellently to the Monopoly Deal game. The game has enough resource management and player interactivity to keep people's interest. The fact that rent is normally collected on all players means that the game is more involving than other card games whose 'hate' cards normally target a single player. This also makes it more engaging to the other players. Since almost all of the actionable cards outside of the player's turn are located in front of them, the game is more even than, say, Munchkin, where all the 'hate' cards come at the person at level 9, leaving the second most advanced player a huge opening to take the game.

I'd say the most intriguing part of this game is each turn offers many opportunities to build an offensive and defensive structure that operates outside of the player's turn. This means that the game feels more strategic and less chaotic that one would expect of a game that is played very quickly. But this is perhaps because it's so easy to learn since it uses some mechanics and concepts from the original game. It does not take long for someone to realize the value of certain cards or to internalize the importance of careful planning.

title: GREAT - fast paced and fun!
text:
Monopoly Deal is a great game. My brother and I (30-somethings) played so many two-person rounds I can't even count. It's fast-paced and depending on your familiarity with the rules and strategies, a full game lasts about 20-30 min, in my opinion. What I loved in particular is how it is truly a game you can play with two people and still have the full experience and strategy. We also got our mom to play with us, and she enjoyed it, too. There is definitely strategy involved in terms of what cards to lay out, what cards to bank, what cards to hold in your hand, and timing of taking actions. The rules might sound complex when you start, but after a round or two, it's easy to pick up. Tip: We typically bank house and hotel cards since the game is so fast that we don't have as much time to lay out a full property set, add a house/hotel, and collect rent (if we had an appropriate rent card in our hands).

My only criticism - and this is rather minor - is there are a handful of scenarios for which no set rules are included in the instructions. In this case, we made our own "house rules" and applied those consistently.

Overall, a super fun game, and I bought a second set b/c my brother kept mine when I headed out after the holidays.

title: BEST FAMILY CARD GAME
text: I was shocked at how much I liked this game when my coworker introduced it to me while we were on the road together for business. I immediately bought it myself and took it on several family vacations. Parents, Siblings, Nieces, Nephews, Cousins, Second Cousins, all of them LOVED IT. It's almost the only game we play while on vacation - the only downside is that its only a 2 - 5 player game.  2 player is great, my wife and I can play it together. 5 players limits when we play it somewhat. Wish it was an 8 player game.  It is MUCH faster and MUCH more fun than Monopoly. You can finish a round in 5 - 10 minutes.

title: Five Stars
text: Whenever I suggest teaching Monopoly Deal to a new group of people, they expect it to be similar to the board game. But it's definitely not! This card game is awesome. It requires a bit of strategy and a bit of luck. It's fast-paced and sometimes frustrating, but it's always a good time. Super high replayability so it never gets stale or boring like its board game predecessor. Overall, five stars. Highly recommend.

title: Fun game, couple of minor tweaks for better game play
text:
I've been playing Monopoly Deal for over a year now and this is one my fav 2-to-5 player games. Fun on planes, snowy days or just hanging around the dinner table. This is loads of fun, tho I do have the following suggestion:

3-to-5 players: Play using the standard rules, 3 property sets to win.
2 players: Increase the number of property sets to win to 5, this will play much better.

It doesn't specifically say it in the rules but if a player already has a set of one color, then I recommend adding a rule that a single player cannot have two sets of the same color (If Player A has Boardwalk & Park Place as a set and then get Player A plays a Blue/Green wild, it has to be used as a Green). Players B/C/D/E can still use the wild however they like. This adds a little more strategy.

Enjoy and Happy Gaming!

title: Buy it right meow
text:
This game is like a family-friendly version of Yu-gi-oh, or Magic the Gathering. It's highly addictive, especially if you're a competitive person like myself.

You win by collecting three complete sets of properties, with each set comprising three or two properties. In the process, you can screw over your friends by collecting taxes on them, stealing their property, or forcing them to trade properties (no doesn't actually mean no).

I like to tell people that they've UNVEILED MY TRAP CARD. Kudos if you get the reference.

It was nice to see my boys pick up the game really quick and become skilled at building property sets and depevoling strategies to win. Is not really about accumulating houses or properties but about working with the cards you have to win the game. There are several turns high and lows! Super exciting! The game can take anywhere from 10-15 minutes, at times a little longer. This allows us to play multiple times. So much fun! We take this with us when we go out to eat dinner and on trips.

title: Fun and more strategy than you think
text:
I got this for my husband and I to take on our annual trip to Mexico. We go to an all-inclusive resort to lay around and do nothing but this year, we thought we'd take some simple card games along for rainy days. I got this Monopoly card game a few months ahead of the trip so we could try it out first. We ended up playing it quite a bit at home since the COVID-19 restrictions hit just after I got the game. It is easy to learn and actually has a lot more strategy involved than you would think at first. We usually get in a "best of three" before we're ready to put it aside.
It's very portable and durable and I look forward to playing it again in Mexico, if/when we can travel!

title: I LOVE games and I especially love card games
text:
Disclaimer: I LOVE games and I especially love card games. I've always enjoyed monopoly but it takes so long to play a round, I don't always want to play it, especially at a game night, when we want to play a few different games, monopoly just takes to long.....enter Monopoly Deal!

It has a quick game play (15 min on average) but maintains the competitiveness/fun of monopoly. You can steal property from others, force trades, and fine or tax them. It's not too hard to explain or understand, so it's perfect for most ages.

We played this with our friends on Sunday, and I told my husband to order it the next day! Really fun addition!

title: So much fun!
text:
We love this game. It's more Monopoly themed and less like the actual game of Monopoly in terms of the length of the game or goal to win. The game can easily be played within 10-15 minutes. Where it is similar is the players can get quite cutthroat and friendships ruined (in a funny, humorous way, of course).

With that said, I'm not giving 5 Stars because this version itself has a low quality of the actual playing cards. They are thin, flimsy, and I am confident they won't last with extended game-play compared to other versions of this game I've played or a standard deck of playing cards.

title: Very Fun Game - And easy to store!
text: Yesterday I played over a dozen rounds of this game with my kids - 9 & 11 years old - and we still want to play more. It's a little complicated to learn, and the instructions don't have answers to all possible scenarios, but overall it's a very fun game. Strategy-wise it's much more like card games than the Monopoly board game. Liking or disliking Monopoly is not a prerequisite, but you need a little patience to learn the game play. One of the things I like most about Monopoly Deal is that it's anyone's game until the end. You don't have players dropping out, losing, or bored for over half an hour, like with the board game. There isn't really any dealing or negotiating. I highly recommend this for game lovers.

title: Go-To Filler
text:
Easy to teach. Fast gameplay. Super portable. Nobody ever says "no" to round.

I've played more hours of Monopoly Deal than any other game I own because it is so easy to bring to the table. People in the know know and those that are new recognize the Monopoly branding and "get it" within a few minutes.

title: Incredible Deal, Highly Recommended
text:
Amazing game and an unbelievable deal for $4. I bought this as a cheap Amazon addon to try with my kids. The setup is easy, just hand each player 5 cards. No distributing money, no picking game pieces, no deciding who is the banker. As each person takes their turn, they draw 2 cards. During their turn they can play any 3 in any combination they choose. Play a game or two and the concept will just click with players.

I'm a huge fan of classic Monopoly and this might actually be more fun and exciting than the board game. It's fantastic how quickly games go.

Pros: Fast 20 minute games, no major setup, no board, simple rules, no more trade issues.

Negatives: Cheap box, some of the cards look similar which can make it harder for younger players.

I think Monopoly Deal would still be a great value even at $10.

title: Love this game, hate your friends
text: Amazing game. You might lose a few friends/family members over it, but it's totally worth it. The rules are incomplete for all situations, so prepare to enact some new legislation... or google it, there's a great monodeal online community.

title: Good game, but feel free to add your own house rules.

-The cards can be a bit transparent in direct light.

title: Easy to play & portable
text: My children love this easy to play & portable game. They were even able to teach their Grandmother how to play.

title: Loads of Fun and Quick Game Play
text:
It takes a few rounds to really get the hang of the rules, but once you do this is a very fun and easy to play game. Great for travel or just when you want a quick game with no hassel, there is little to set up or clean up here. Four rules cards are included for quick reference for all the players.

Game Play: The object of the game is to collect 3 full property sets before anyone else does. To do this, you'll manage property cards, money cards (which allow you to build your bank - important so that you don't have to pay other players with your properties), and action cards (which allow you to collect rent, steal properties, sue other players, and more). The properties will be famliar to regular Monopoly players, but most of the other aspects of this game are new.

We had a great time playing Monopoly Deal on a recent family vacation while waiting for the evening's activities to begin. Shuffling the cards and dealing out the first hand was the extent of the setup. Once we were done, we just put all the cards back in the box - that's all the clean-up that's required. It's great for all ages and not the huge time commitment that a full board game requires.

text: This is our go to game for family events. Everyone we have introduced it to love it as well. HOWEVER, make sure you get the GREEN copy of the game. There is a newer BLUE box version. The GREEN copy has great artwork and is clear to read and understand the rules. The BLUE version is very difficult to read, has worse art, and really makes it harder to teach and to play.

title: Never play regular monopoly again!
text: I hate regular monopoly. It lasts too long and some people refuse to make deals. This on the other hand lasts about 15 minutes and has plenty of replay value. It's easy to get the hang of quickly. Less rules and pieces - No board, cash, banker, etc. Some of the cards are used so rarely that I would have left them out - such as hotels/houses. They typically get used as cash instead. I love being able to take people's property and the Just Say No card. It does seem to be my luck that a lot of the time I have either a lot of properties without the rent cards or lots of the rent cards with no properties to match. Overall, we enjoy this game.

text: Really fun game that's quick and easy to play! You still need a lot of strategy to win and it's more challenging than the regular monopoly (I guess it depends on who you play with). Love how games are quick and every game is completely different than the last.

title: Monopoly lovers and haters will fall in love with this family friendly card game.
text: Let me start off by saying that whether you love traditional monopoly like me or if you hated being forced to play a 5 hour board game with no end in site you will fall in love with Monopoly Deal. It has all the fun of the monopoly game with great twists and features that make it exciting to play and everyone will love it. You might get lucky and win in 15 minutes or you could spend more time collecting your 3 sets of properties. Its compact and great to take on the go for travel or a waiting room time killer. Its easy enough that kids can grasp all the rules quickly and it comes with little rule cards to refresh and remind you as you play. The best part is that there are only a few rules to play the game. You don't have to spend 20 minutes reading a 4 page manual and setting up a million pieces to play this fun, fast paced, family friendly game.

title: Great Fun!  A very mean and wonderfully quick game.
text:
This is a great game - absolutely worth it, especially since the price often dips below $5. Others have given their thoughts, but here is my quick summary.

Gameplay: Make 3 sets of properties, either by luck of the draw, or swiping them from your opponents . It's a take-that type game, where some of the best laid plans get blown up. We have played with 2, 3 and 4 players and gameplay is about 10 to 15 minutes. Outside of a first game, I have not seen a need to handicap for younger players (>9 yrs).

Components - the cards are a little on the thin side, but that can be expected for the price point, and the number of cards in the deck. The box will wear out quickly, so a cheap deck box would be a necessary accessory.

Our thoughts: This is the only version of Monopoly that we would play. This game was a Christmas stocking gift for the 10-year old. He carried it around throughout the holiday, and even taught the babysitter when we got back home. It's learned quickly, and never played just once. It's frustrating, hilarious, and certain to have at least one person shouting for a rematch. Highly recommended for a quick travel game.

title: Fresh take on a classic
text:
My older sister loves original monopoly but it was always such a hassle to keep track of all the literal moving parts, and I was rarely willing to sacrifice hours of my life every time she wanted to play. Then I found this.

This version of monopoly is fantastic. Easy to learn, simple design (and no cursed tiny pieces) and multiple ways to play the same cards. If you're a money grabber, you can bankrupt people. If you like to hoard properties, you can be the baddest realitor on the block. If you like to play shrewed strategy and pit your opponents against each other, you can do that too! The 3 types of cards can all be played in different ways so everyone can play however they want in order to monopolize the game.

I have only played with other adults, but I'm sure kids will be able to pick up on this game easily as well. If you like to play quickly, you can. Or, if you like to get more competitive, you can stretch a game out to about half an hour. Either way, you never have to fear being trapped in a hellish 6 hour game that makes you feel like time has stopped, or worry about losing a little plastic house that you will step on later.

A true 10/10.

title: I hate Monopoly, but I LOVE Monopoly Deal
text: The thing I hate about the Monopoly board game is because it's a bored game. It's as boring as it gets, and it goes on and on and on. I've never found any satisfaction playing the board game. Enter Monopoly Deal. I only just started playing this with my kids, and boy it's FUN! There are a few reasons for this. Firstly, it's a fast game - we often finish a game in about 10 minutes. Secondly, because it's a card game, we can pack up quick and easily. Thirdly, the mechanics is MUCH more exciting and unpredictable - I'll explain. Most people like the "Chance" or "Community Chest" cards where you can get a good or bad turn of events - that element of "luck"? Well this WHOLE game is like playing "Chance" or "Community Chest" cards - things change fast, and that's the fun of it. All in all, Monopoly sucks, but Monopoly Deal rocks!

text: I got this card monopoly game for my granddaughter's visit. When you read the rules, you will be completely confused, so do what the instructions say at the end: just start playing! This is a game about conivary - you quickly understand that to shame against other players (but still have fun) is the point of this fast-paced game. And, it doesn't take hours or days to play with thousands of little parts! A deck of cards and in fifteen minutes or less, the winner will surface. It isn't only fun with kids, either. Try playing it with other couples! Because it is about who can be the best con man in a short period of time, you will find yourself playing several hands and still wanting to play one more!

title: IT'S BACKKKK
text:
After what feels like ages, it appears that Hasbro has finally listened to the masses and decided to reprint the original Monopoly Deal... After they tried to change the game into the disaster called Millionaire Deal, it seems they've learned from their mistakes.
This is a duplicate of the original first edition card for card, with no changes, exactly as it should be!

title: You will have habitual one-night stands with this game
text:
You will (probably) love it, and break up with it every night you play.

This game is as destructive as "real" monopoly to your friendships and relationships. Lots of fun, if people are willing to have victory snatched from their palms and not hold a grudge afterward (which WILL happen). It stings for longer because the actual rules have no room for coming in second, or third, or what have you.

Easy enough to double up the decks and play with more people, but gameplay slows down too much for enjoyability with more than five people.

If you love the "real" game, however, the sneakiness of special cards and how you must play this like a legit card game may be annoying to you. Just keep in mind that this is not Monopoly, it is a Monopoly-based UNO like game.

I didn't even realize how fortunate we were to have had the opportunity of buying the green version until I wanted to buy another one, and it WASN'T available! I'm definitely keeping an eye out for another of the green version, but we gifted our nephew (really, his parents) with a blue version. I can let everyone know how that one fares in comparison when it comes in and we all play it! You will definitely not be disappointed! The instructions may seem a bit overwhelming, but, as the box promises, it'll all become clearer when you're playing! Have fun!

Probably one of THE most enjoyable card games ever! I bought 2 decks, because 1 isn't enough for 4+ players (we slightly modify the rules with identical properties, etc). Very fast to pick up, fun strategies can be used, some very powerful cards to "ruin" friendships and marriages . . . :)

title: Our whole family loves this game!!
text: We have 4 kids ranging from 15-23 (3 are away at college).  It seems that after every meal everyone disperses and are always on their phones.  My hubby and I really wanted to find a game that we could all play together to keep us connected and together over Christmas break.  Someone recommended Monopoly Deal so we checked it out on Amazon and saw a ton of great reviews so we purchased it.  This game is so fun!!  Our whole family enjoyed it and we played it a ton of times while all the kids were home.  One of the great things about it is that games are done in 15 min so you can play multiple games if you have time or only a couple and you're not committed to 4 hours or an entire evening.  If one kid had to leave, the rest of us could still play.  We also brought it along when we visited our out-of-town family for New Years and taught them (and it's so cheap you can buy several and give them away) and everyone loved it.  We also bought some for our college kids to bring back to school.  If you're considering this game. BUY IT NOW, it's well worth it and a lot of fun!!

It is easy enough for a nine year old to understand but also challenging for adults (and kids) at the same time.  This is also great for traveling as it packs well, just a size of two deck of cards.

title: Wonderful Card-Version for a Classic Board favorite
text:
WE LOVE to play this game! If you love monopoly but do not want to commit to the hours it takes to play the actual board game, then you probably would really enjoy this card game version. We can play several rounds in 30 minutes, and since the odds/favors start over with each new hand, EVERYONE can enjoy winning a game here and there!

My kids begin understanding the concepts (with our help and guidance) at about 4-5 yrs old, and by the time they are 6, they are fairly strategic and equally as challenging of opponents as any of the adults! I hope that these continue to stay in production, but I think I will go ahead and buy several to have for the years to come.

title: Fun, easy to learn. Even if you don‚Äôt like the board game version!
text:
I hate monopoly but was introduced to this card game version- and it was actually extremely fun and easy to pick up (that said, I still haven‚Äôt won a game).

Lots of different strategies you can try out to win, from what I‚Äôve gathered from the people that beat me. Definitely some luck in the cards you draw but you can outwit opponents.

A few things missing in the rules, some ambiguities but not a big deal.

title: Hours of fun
text: This game has provided our family hours and hours of fun. We've have become completely addicted to it! We bought it for a road trip, though it is a bit cumbersome to play in the car because you have to lay out your cards in front of you. But in the past month, we have played it nearly every day and frequently we play 4-6 games in one day. I love that everyone has fun playing, my husband and I enjoy ourselves as much as our 8-year old does. Our niece was visiting last weekend and she too got addicted to it too! My niece and son were already making plans to play the game together when they see each other this summer.

title: Great game
text: My six year old grandson loves the monopoly board game but it takes so long to play it. This card game is so terrific. It took us about 45 minutes to play it the first time in order to understand the directions and get the rhythm of the game. Now it takes about 15 to 20 minutes to play a game. It is fun and challenging,  a matter of strategy as well as luck. When we don‚Äôt have hours to play the board game we play the card game. My grandson is entering the second grade and he can read the cards and follow the directions.

title: Creative twist on Monopoly concepts
text: I don't like to play regular Monopoly because it takes too long. This game shares concepts from the original Monopoly, but is otherwise a completely different game that can be played in about 30 minutes. It's fun as a 2-player game or with more players, though the strategy changes as more players are involved. Game is rated for ages 8+, but our 7 yr old is able to play it, possibly better than all of us. Easy to learn, yet challenging enough that I still haven't figured out the best strategy or if there even is a single best strategy. Compact for bringing along on travels, but allow extra space to spread out the cards that have been played. Don't try to play it on the plane or you will be digging around under seats for the cards that fell off the tray table.

text:
Wow! This takes the place of my favorite and first go-to game of any game night, I don't know how I never heard of this but it makes playing the other classic board Monopoly rather pointless haha. This is quicker, more wild back and forth play, on edge, strategy based in many ways, and exciting every time. You'll be a little confused or overwhelmed a little at first but read the instructions over and over part by part, it'll come to you quicker and more clearly in no time... As it says itself, once you play then you'll understand haha.

I recommend playing a Tutorial Round or two where everyone shows their cards and discusses eachother strategies per play they're thinking at given times which will make playing the game 10x easier and quicker to understand during Tutorial phase - You'll learn so much that way and then when you play normal from there on, everyone will never want to stop!

title: 21st Century Monopoly
text: This card game requires more strategy than the original board game. You collect money for your "bank" and then lay out property cards. The first player to create 3 sets of property wins the game. There are "action" cards where property can be taken away or rent charged to other players. My siblings and I changed many of the rules of the original Monopoly board game to allow for more strategizing. Now, not only can you can play in the car or the airport, you can do more than roll the dice and cross your fingers.

text: This is a fun, quicker paced Monopoly-themed card game for multiple players.  Our family plays this when a longer lasting game isn't possible. title: Love Monopoly but hate the endless play?
text:
I always liked Monopoly, but it gets really disappointing when somebody gets bankrupt out of the game and then it goes on for another hour--or more! This card game has all the same features and strategies, but it's quick. I think the average play time was about 15 minutes, with four players.

It takes a while to figure out, and you have to read and listen carefully to the instructions, but once you get the hang of it, it moves quickly and lasts about the right amount of time to be entertaining. We recently played with five adults in one after-dinner session. Three of us played for the first time. We had big fun and played three games before we had had enough for the evening.

I look forward to playing again. I recommend it as an excellent alternative to the often-tedious board game.

I liked that they mentioned it can be played in 15 minutes right on the front because monopoly is notoriously known for taking ALL NIGHT to play.

This has become one of the funnest card games I ever played. Doesn't take long to get used to playing it so once my wife and I got the hang of, we played quite a few rounds (yes, it can be played in 15 minutes) the first night. title: We love how much faster this is to play than regular ...
text: My son is obssessed with this game. We love how much faster this is to play than regular Monopoly. Also regular monopoly has some inevitability, whatever player has the most monopolies will win. This game is more unpredictable, you can be down, and get cards to steal from others, and end up winning over someone who is "almost winning". I love that about this game. This combined with the portability, and we have been playing this game more often than most family board games we have purchased in the last few years.

title: If you like Monopoly (board game), you will like this too.
text:
I bought it because a deal site showed it and I said why not... My 10 year old enjoys the regular monopoly game.

After opening the game, my daughter wanted to play instantly. I started reading her all the rules... I understood 50% of the rules and she barely understood a few! I told her that I will take a few minutes in peace to understand them. They turned out to be not hard at all and my daughter got all the rules in the first few minutes of the actual game play. So, my recommendation is not to daunt kids with the rules... Explain each rule at appropriate moment while playing and they will get it.

The lovely part is that this game can finish in 5-30 minutes, against the Monopoly board game that needs at least an hour. If you like Monopoly, I think you will like this card game. If you want to teach Monopoly to kids, I think the board game is the first step.

And, I love the special deal cards such as Sly deal, Deal breaker, Say no, etc.

Overall, it's nice addition to my card games collection and it's worth the money.

title: game involves Luck & Skill. Faster moving game than regular monopoly, not time to get bored.
text: This is a really fun game. It's also easy to catch on, especially if one of the players has played before. It's sometimes hard to find games with just 2 players, there seem to be more for 3 or more players. My husband and I have often played games, just the 2 of us. It was nice to find one that is Fun & can be 2 or more players. When we've had friends over to play this game, they liked it so much, they wanted to take it home to barrow it.  Sometimes the player that was losing at the beginning, ends up being the winner.  This game has both Luck & skill involved. It's also more fast moving and not as boring the regular monopoly can be. You can acquire properties much faster, and trade properties as well.

You won't regret getting this card game oh, I highly recommend it. Can also take it for when you travel or just when you go to a party or even when the kids are bored... Highly Entertaining!

title: Quick and fun version of Monopoly
text: Monopoly Deal is now our ‚Äúgo to‚Äù card game. Remember those epic long Monopoly games as a kid? Well, this takes the best of Monopoly board game and compacts it into a game that lasts 20 minutes or so. It is super fun and you can still be evil with large rents. There are new ways of being evil, like stealing or trading properties. Highly recommend! Very compact, easy to learn, easy to play and hardly any cleanup. Just shuffle!

title: Simple yet fun for 2-5 players.
text: This card game is "Monopoly made fun".  It's much quicker then the old board game and there's more strategy involved.  The game is easy to learn and has many twists and turns involved.  You get to steal properties from other players which makes it interesting.  The fun part is that you can be pretty much bankrupt and out of property during one turn and completely turn it around and win the game the next turn.  It's also nice because although this game is most interesting with 4 or 5 players, it's fun with just 2 players.

title: Great alternative to the board game

title: Fun and quick

It doesn't replace the boars game, of course, but is a decent substitute that's easy to pack along to have something to play with friends or family wherever you go.

title: Fun take on monopoly
text: Fun game and can be quicker than normal monopoly

title: The only way to play Monopoly
text: Such a fun, quick, competitive game of Monopoly! I don't like playing the board game as it usually takes forever and I get bored. But Monopoly Deal you can play in 15 minutes or less, and is way more competitive than the board game. Super easy to learn, and a great game to play with friends or to destroy siblings.

title: Definitely buy this game!
text: This is mine and my fianc√©'s favorite game. We first bought it a few years ago and after playing it 1000 times it was time for a fresh set. Unlike the original Monopoly, games are quick (certainly within 20 minutes the game is finished), which means that you and your friends can play several games before calling it a night, which will probably be pretty late because you won't realize how much time has passed and you'll be playing for best 6 out of 11. I have brought this game with me to houses of friends and family and they all end up having a blast. It only takes 1 game to learn the rules too which definitely helps. I recommend playing this game with 3-5 people as well. You will not regret buying this game, it's inexpensive and worth every penny!

title: You‚Äôll love it!

title: So much fun you'll wear out the cards!
text:
I've played many, many, many, many games of Monopoly Deal. So much so that the cards are starting to show some wear and tear. I wish they were more durable.

It's only tenuously related to Monopoly so there's no epic all-evening game that slogs on to an inevitable end. You *can* play all night but in 5-10 minute intervals. Easy to learn but deep strategy if you pay attention.

There are a couple of scenarios that aren't covered in the rules but we've adapted house rules to cover them. (eg: Just Say No! cards count as an action for the player whose turn it is. Houses/hotels built on properties can't be used to pay other players.)

text:
Every person I've introduced this game to LOVES this game. I played this game all the way back in 2012 and only four years later randomly thought of it and how much I absolutely adored playing it. I bought it and now my boyfriend, roommate, friends all love playing it to. Really good to play while other things are going on, too (like at a party, or while a football game is on TV or something), because you can only half pay attention when it's not your turn and still have fun.

My roommate, boyfriend, and I probably play it multiple times a week.

title: Great Substitution for the Board Game
text:
Monopoly deal is a great game and an awesome substitution to the board game especially while on the go. The card version of the game takes no time at all to play compared to the board game that can take hours. My family plays this game often playing several rounds through a night. It is a different spin to the game, but grabs the attention of older kids that don‚Äôt care for games at all. This makes it nice since they actually want to play and soon find themselves wanting to play over and over.
There are several different action card such as ‚ÄúJust Say No‚Äù when a player trying to take property or make you pay a huge amount of rent. In addition, there are extra turn cards that can be used to increase your chances of winning. Also, there are cards that allow you swap properties with someone or to steal a whole set, but it can be countered with a ‚ÄúJust Say No‚Äù.
We play it two different ways ‚Äì one whoever gets 3 full properties wins or whoever get a certain amount of money wins. The winner of the previous game usually chooses which we will do. Most of the time the games are used to make deals of who wins they get something or a loser owes the winner something.
We keep two sets at home and one in each vehicle so that if we are ever anywhere that a game would add some fun we whip it out. As long as we have been playing we have yet to find anyone that does not get addicted to playing the game and has to go out and buy their own set.

title: Way more fun than you'd think
text:
My family of three (two adults and an 8 year old) have played this game every night since its arrival two weeks ago, but adult groups also have a blast with it: It's quick, easy to learn and ridiculously fun. Players rely on both strategy and luck, so although it can be cut-throat, players of all levels stand a good chance of winning a game (allowing you to feel clever when you win, but not take it personally when you don't).

When we first started playing, games took a little longer than expected, but once you get in the groove, it's not unreasonable to play a two-person game in 10 minutes, or a 3-person game in 15. We usually end up playing 3-4 games in a night. Definitely a great addition to game night!

title: Best price to fun ratio of any game out there!
text:
One of the best deals you can get! The price is quite reasonable and this product, as far as I know, is not longer sold in stores.

Essential Pros!!:
- gameplay is quickly/EASILY LEARNED, but not so simple that there is only one way to play!
- gameplay TIME is much shorter than regular board games, but does not detract from fun at all! (~10min fewer players, ~30min many players)
- 2-6 PLAYERS, I recommend 3-5 (more than 5 takes a while to reach everyone's turn)
- game is very PORTABLE and easy to keep in a car/backpack/bag/original case
- PRICE is great
- able to play quickly during breaks, but has great REPLAY VALUE for hours in a sitting
- much more understandable skill-based + luck-based game; not purely luck like other games (AS IN REGULAR MONOPOLY!)

Cons:
- a few house rules may be needed (just 1 or 2)
- extending to more than 5 players makes the game very long; not that it was intended for 7, 8, 9 players, but seemed to be a reasonable warning for some people who may be looking for a larger party game

Quick Gameplay Breakdown:
- Each player starts with 5 cards, Draws 2 per turn, Plays a max of 3 per turn, 7 card hand max
- If the player exceeds 7 cards in their hand by the end of their turn (the 3 cards played) they must discard cards into the used pile until they have 7

- To win the game is to collect any 3 sets (the original monopoly sets; as in Boardwalk + Parkplace are a set of 2 cards, All the railroads are a set of 4 cards)

- Action cards can be used and discarded OR played in front of you as money (and will stay as money when exchanged)
- Almost everything [Property, Money, Action cards] has a monetary value, so you can choose what to pay with
- There is NO change for the game; if someone charges you $1M and you only have a $10M you have no choice
- You can only pay with cards played in front of you (not your hand); so if you are charged $10M but have nothing, you pay nothing
-------------------- Essentially those last 3~4 make the game quite tricky

title: This card game version is 10x better than the original board game
text:
This card game version is 10x better than the original board game. The action cards keep the game interesting, allowing you to steal or swap properties from other players. The rent system is also well designed and can really turn the tide earlier in a game when players do not have a good money stockpile. The game has a surprisingly high depth of strategy even though it is easily taught, and in my opinion, these are the best games with non-gamers.

It is easily one of our goto family games with friends from out of town!

title: We really needed this.
text:
Five years.

Five years of parenthood. Five years of diaper changes, mess cleaning, feeding, wiping, carrying, pushing, and struggling. It's been five years since we could play games like we used to, and we've really missed it.

This game has the same backstabbing capitalism of the board game, but without the need to set up the board and expose the play money to the whims of children. There's no way we'd get away with the full setup. They'd rush in with their grubby hands and pull it off the table. Someone would swallow a Hotel. We'd be finding play money in the vents for years!

Owning this game has returned us to the glory of casual competitive play. We make a quick date out of it. So far, we haven't played with others, and as such the money-based hazards rarely come into play, but we still have a blast.

I really missed all the accusations of cheating.

title: [Honestly] Fast Dealing Property Game
text:
It's hard to get friends to commit to a game of anything if you use the word "Monopoly" - but this variant is well designed and allows for many strategies to come forward.

I even took this to work and my co-workers and I knock out a game or two while on our lunch break. It's especially nice that you don't need a large area to play. I'd be interested to see if this variant becomes subject to the normal 'themed' Monopoly craze that has taken it's older cousin by storm (e.g. Star Wars Monopoly Deal card game?).

Overall, a good and most importantly _fast_ game that doesn't make you want to flip over the table.

title: Game for Everyone
text:
This is the vintage design version (with a nod to the original game everyone knows). This design [with the green box] is certainly much better. This card game takes the best elements of monopoly and actually turns it into a much faster and playable card game. We've been playing this one for a couple of years, and it still rises to the top of the pile.

It's just a deck (which includes property cards, money cards, rent cards, house and hotel cards, pass go cards -- draw 2, and lucky cards that allow you to steal and trade or collect money). The cards all have a simple $ value assigned to them. The objective is to get three property sets to win.

The whole family plays it -- including our children (age ten and thirteen). We play a lot of games (including strategy, deck-building, RPG, and cooperative games). Elementary school kids should have no problem playing it. It's the kind of game that is fast to teach, utilizes a combo of luck and strategy (which keeps it light), and is very portable (for trips or picnics). We've been able to gift this to other families and kids, and everyone has loved it.

title: Quick, transportable form of Monopoly
text:
Fun card game that can take far less time than the Monopoly board game and may even require more strategy than the up-to-chance roll of the dice in the board game version. Not too difficult to learn and not many rules - the rules could be clearer about some things, but perhaps they intended you to decide yourself.

There is one rule I change when playing. The rules state that once a person has 3 property sets, the game is over, and that person wins, making money in your bank not very crucial. So, I play that the game ends, but the person who has the most money (including value of property) wins. This typically extends the game a bit since a person needs to make sure they have the most money before obtaining 3 sets, but I would say it makes the game better. You're welcome :)

title: This game brought my family together!
text: No words can describe how grateful I am to have bought this game. For the last few years it's been incredibly difficult getting our family of four together and happy, even during holidays. Yesterday night for Christmas I pulled out monopoly deal and for the first time in ages ALL 4 of us wanted to stay in the same room for more than the usual! We laughed, laugh-cried, and played almost 15  "one more round"s (hah!). It's super fun and easy to learn. Even my mom who doesn't know english well was able to catch on, and she ENJOYED it too (she usually despises games). Dad wasn't retreating to man cave, and little brother wasn't grumpy or rushing to see friends. Everyone wanted to keep playing and conspire over who to kill next. If you ever want to see mid-20 and mid-50 year olds acting like children again, this is the perfect game for you. I am SO GLAD I bought this game.

title: 5 minutes rather than 5 hours

title: Purple Phoenix Games Review
text:
Yep. You read that correctly. This is a review of Monopoly Deal. Classic Monopoly gets a bad rap from almost all gamers, and I know we are all tired of saying, ‚ÄúNo, not like Monopoly‚Äù when asked about our gaming hobby. But how does this card version of the game hold up? Is it any better than the original, or is it still destined for the ‚ÄúTo Sell‚Äù pile?

Monopoly Deal is a game of hand management, set collection, and take that as players are trying to collect 3 complete property sets. Setup is simple ‚Äì shuffle the deck of cards and deal 5 to each player, put the remaining cards in a draw pile, and determine the starting player. On your turn, you will complete 3 steps: draw 2 cards, play up to 3 cards, and discard your hand down to 7 cards if necessary. Play then continues clockwise to the next player. There are 3 different ways in which you can play your cards. You can play money into your bank, add properties to your collection, or play action cards to the center of the table. Action cards allow you to do things like charge opponents rent or draw additional cards. The game ends once a player has completed 3 complete property sets. Be the first to do so, and you are the winner!

I know you‚Äôre dying to get to the point ‚Äì is this card game any good? I do have to admit that it has its good points. The game is easy to learn and fast to play. One of the worst parts of the board game version is that it feels like it takes an eternity to play. As a card game, the flow is faster and that makes it more engaging for all players the entire time. The rules are simple and clear, and there is no ambiguity as to how different cards work. Don‚Äôt want a property? Just don‚Äôt play it! There‚Äôs no need to send it to auction like in the board game, just discard it when you get a chance. This card game version simplifies the board game in a way that makes it enjoyable.

The biggest downside for me regarding Monopoly Deal is that this game is based mostly on the luck of the draw. It is very difficult to create a strategy because you are at the mercy of your hand of cards. No matter how hard you try, or how adept you are at strategy games, if the deck of cards is working against you, it is very difficult to bounce back. Another part of this game that I do not like is the take that aspect. I‚Äôve said it before, I do not enjoy direct confrontation in games. I can be pretty competitive and I begin to take things personally, which makes the game fun for nobody. This game can get pretty cutthroat, and because of the large luck element, it can feel unbalanced and unfair. Parts of it feel kind of Munchkin-y to me, and it brings down my enjoyment factor.

For such a light and luck-based game, Monopoly Deal really has a little more to it than meets the eye. Is it better than the board game version? In my opinion, yes. I would much rather play the card game than the board game. That being said, I reserve this game more for a filler game or an introductory game for newer gamers ‚Äì it‚Äôs not one that I am dying to pull out at every opportunity. Should you give it a try? That‚Äôs ultimately up to you, but I think you might be surprised with this game. Overall, Purple Phoenix Games gives Monopoly Deal a 6 / 12.

title: Fun little game and easy to learn
text: Fun little game and easy to learn. The instructions make it sound a bit more complicated than it actually is. There's an element of luck, to be sure, but lots of strategy involved in this game, too. And it is brutally cut-throat, especially if you allow players to make deals with each other to swap properties and/or cash already on the table. For 2 to 5 people - and I'm told if you buy a second copy and mix the two decks together, you can play with even more people... you may need to find a larger dining-room table!

One thing we do, especially when only 2 or 3 people are playing is to use the "Deal Breaker" card only as money. This card allows you to steal a complete set of cards from another play (need 3 sets to win). Game ends too quickly when this card is used, therefore, we use it for the money value only.

text: This made the perfect gift. It is fairly easy to learn, you need to read the instructions and pay attention to the special cards. It is not the best for travel as in playing in a car or airplane because you still need to lay cards down. It is very portable and fits easily in a purse/backpack/carryon. title: Very fun game to play for small to larger groups of friends and family
text: The game is easy to learn a a lot of fun once everyone gets the hang of it. More players, means a more challenging game. If this is your first time playing it, do read the instructions once and do a test round, and you're good to go. You can also bend the rules a little if you want to make things a little more interesting. I bought this for a christmas gift exchange last year and the recipient was very happy to received it. title: Different take on traditional Monopoly
text:
Great game that is a different take on the traditional Monopoly. The directions are a bit confusing, but just as it states, it's clear once you start playing.
The way the instructions are laid out, it makes it fair to all players so someone can't hold properties and lay them all down at once.
It's a fun game and can be played under the age of 8 if you don't play too aggressively against them.
Game times will vary. One game lasted 10 minutes while another lasted close to 30 minutes.
Overall, it's a fun game and the concept is easier than Monopoly but just as fun!

title: Do you like playing Monopoly
text:
Do you have time to play Monopoly? Of course not! Do you like playing Monopoly? Of course not! Who wants to waste hours of their life on some game that raises your hopes of being able to make a lot of money when you know very well that you will never make more than $100,000 a year? NO ONE! So do yourself a favor, save some time, and have fun screwing your friends over while playing Monopoly deal. YOU. WILL. NEVER. REGRET. IT. NEVER.
NEVER.
EVER.

title: Fun game with lots of strategies and surprises. The best part is no longer to deal with tons of paper money and little pieces!
text:
My son always loves to play traditional Monopoly since he was five. But the traditional Monopoly takes too much time to play and have too many pieces (a lot of different dollar bills, green color houses, red color hotels, etc), the rest of family (parents, uncles and aunts) all hesitate to play with him. It takes forever to play Monopoly and have tons of things to take care of.

Now, I found this Monopoly Deal Family Card game and can't believe how much fun this game is within around 15 minutes for a round. This is such a great design to combine strategy, luck and excitement for school age kids and grown up together. My son just turns 9 years old and loves to play the set because he can think about different strategies to try to make the wining sets. Now the grown up also have tons of fun because this game makes you think also provides lots of surprise. The only huge bonus is you can bring this card game to any place easily since it eliminate all the paper money and lots of pieces. The price is really inexpensive. I will buy this game as gifts to all my son's friends for them to play with their families. This is how much I love this game! Highly recommend!

Although I will admit, the "play in 15 minutes" that they advertise is a bit of an understatement, games take us like 20-30 minutes unless we are playing at light speed. Overall a really fun game and would highly recommend - great for bringing to the bar and playing with your friends or just playing at home.

Pro tip - if you are a rules stickler, there are more specific rules online if you just google them (the ones that come with the game don't cover a lot of the "edge case" scenarios that you might run across).

title: Like Uno & monopoly? You'll LOVE this game!
text:
Such a fun game, it's Monopoly strategy with the speed and playing style of UNO. You can teach a group by playing the first round with "open face cards" to show your hand and everybody easily picks up on the strategy. If players remember how to play Monopoly (especially that railroads are 4 and certain properties only take 2 for a monopoly) and they've play uno in the past, they pick it up really quickly.

2 player games can take between 5-15mins; larger games can take 10-25 depending on how familiar the players are with the game.

title: Missing Cards
text:
I purchased the 4 pack of cards but while playing I noticed something odd about the number of blue/green rent cards that I had. Upon cheching all the cards in the 4 packs that I bought against the rules sheet I noticed the following:
1) There were 2 railway cards short
2) There were 2 single rend cards short
3) There were 2 force deal cards short
4) There was 1 dedt collector card short
5) There was 1 just say no card short
6) There was 1 utility card short
7) There was 1 utility/railroad card short
8) There was 1 5 million dollar card short
9) There was 1 sly deal card short
10) There were 4 extra blue/green rent cards

I'm not sure how such a thing could have happened but it it is now difficult to play with the 4 sets. Please ensure that you check all cards properly when you receive them

title: Great, Simple take on a Classic
text:
For fans of Monopoly, let me tell you - This game is even better than Monopoly. Why is that? Remember how in Monopoly you circle the board waiting to earn enough money and hoping to land on just the right space? And then someone else lands on the one piece of property you needed to make up your monopoly? Well, those days are over. This game features every property in Monopoly, but it also has plenty of Wild Cards for each property group so that the odds are you can build a full property set without the need for finding just the right combination. Plus, there are many interesting "dirty tricks" cards that allow one to assemble monopolies through forced trades or outright theft of cards held by other players.
But don't worry there are plenty of such cards. So if you get robbed in one hand, someone else is going to get it right back in the next hand.

Rounds end when one player completes and lays down three monopolies. I have seen many rounds end where several players are within one draw of winning. It plays fast (15-20 minutes per round), and is easy to learn: Start with 5 cards; each turn a player first draws two new cards and can then play up to three cards. No more than 7 cards can remain in a player's hand at the end of their turn. The remainder must be discarded.

Easy. And loads of fun.

title: Not a day goes by‚Ä¶
text:
My kids received this game as a Christmas gift from my Californian pescetarian brother and I can honestly say that not a day has gone by that we have not played it. For a family of 4, this game is a quick 15-minute competition in our home, where the winner gets bragging rights over everyone else for that week. It takes little minds away from iPads, PlayStations, and phones - and brings out laughter and a competitive spirit. Stealing properties, charging rent, and waiting for that perfect move to win the game has become staple moments in our home, and we cannot be happier.
We played it at the airport, the hotel, and the beach due to its convenience, and we easily looked up the rules to secure a win. The only thing to buy with this is extra tape as we already had to reinforce the little box twice from over-use. Bought a second set just in case, or to gift to another family. Well done Monopoly‚Ä¶ well done.

title: Monopoly in Minutes
text:
My Wife and I are somewhat fans of Monopoly. We've played 3 or 4 different versions of the full game. Yet we get tired of the tedious amount of time and counting and all of the unnecessary mundane things that must be done to play the full game.

Monopoly Deal eliminates all of that.

It plays fast, 15-30 minutes, no counting, rules are fun...and what I enjoy most is that it can be far more cutthroat and competitive.

There is some luck involved with the cards you draw, but that adds to the strategy.

We mostly play 2 players and it helps to make the game more competitive if you elimate some doubles/quadruples of certain action cards. For example: Pass Go, Forced Deal, Sly Deal, Deal Breaker...

Although without doing that the game can still be much fun and swing wildy, making for exciting victories or defeats. Even if one person appears to be dominating with bank and properties. You can draw a Deal Breaker and steal a whole property and then draw a card that completes your 3rd and win just like that.

Keep your bank full and build your properties fast.

This is alot of fun and I don't think we'll ever go back to a full board version of Monopoly.

We are excited to teach some friends this game and see how 4 or more players go with this.

Highly recommended. Even for those who despise Monopoly. This is completely different.

title: good family game
text: My 11 and 8 year old daughters enjoy this game.  The 8 year old requested it after playing at a friend's.  We have only had it for a few weeks, so it's hard to tell if the excitement will last, but given that she requested it after playing several times at her friend's, I imagine it will.  The game has some flexibility, which adds some interest (for example, the directions state that the first player to earn 3 monopolies is the winner, but you can easily play until the draw pile runs out, and then call the winner the one with the most assets...).  The game was interesting enough for me as an adult to play along with my daughter, happily enough.  There is some strategy along with luck.  It is based loosely upon the classic Monopoly ideas (to collect properties, create monopolies, collect rent, amass wealth, etc.).

title: Addicting game
text: Definitely have to play with people actually interested in learning to play, but by the third round they‚Äôll be addicted to the game too. I could play it all day. May want to look up some rules that others have used in the game. For example, only the top card of your bank has to be shown to other players.

title: Fun game
text:
Our family likes gaming, with games like Ticket to Ride and Settlers of Catan having become very common. We were looking for something different, and I saw a list suggesting Monopoly Deal is unique. It's pretty good, we all enjoy it! Every game is an up and down adventure... sort of in the vein of Uno, with a little more strategy.
Set was great, only issue we had was it had an extra copy of one of the cheap properties. So check your deck. Some rule situations are less than clearly spelled out, and may take a few games for everyone to totally get the hang of them. But it's definitely got a lot of replay interest! A unique twist!

title: So much fun!
text: The best party card game of all time! My friends and I play where the winner gets to choose a custom rule for the next round. Favorites are: pass go cards are free to play, you can use money from your hand, sly deals completed slyly without the victim noticing doesn't count as a turn, you can buy an increased hand limit of 2 to a max of 9 for X amount of money, the 10 money card can be played to take one of the top 3 cards from the discard pile, etc... This game has lasted among my friend groups for about 7 years now. We keep going back to it. Quick, fun, and many people can play (especially if you play with two decks). Very fun while drinking!

title: New Twist on the Classic Monopoly
text:
I received this as a Christmas gift.

I am so glad that they are selling this game again!

I used to have this, and my mom and I would play it all the time. It was our 'go to' game. But then we stored it in the closet and one day it fell open and somehow all of the cards were lost. We have been looking for a the game for a while now, hoping to replace the old one and could never find it. They just now started selling it again on Amazon and I am beyond happy to have it once again.

The game itself if very consolidated and does not take up nearly as much space as Monopoly. I would rather bring this on a trip than bring the original Monopoly.

The two games are slightly different, though. A game of Monopoly Deal is much shorter than a game of regular Monopoly. Also, in Monopoly Deal one does not buy houses or hotels; instead you must pick up a house or hotel card.

You start off with five cards for each player, and on their turn the player will draw two cards and play three cards. Your goal is to be the first one to get three full sets of properties on the table in front of you. When this happens you win.

The game is good quality. The cards are not so thick that they can't be shuffled and they are not so thin that you would be concerned about bending or tearing them while playing.

The game is simpler than the regular Monopoly, and with a bit of help children should be able to figure it out and play. I plan to teach my 8 year old cousin this game so that he can play it with me.

I highly recommend this product.

title: Fun game for Monopoly lovers who just want a quick, yet fun game!
text:
My 6 year old daughter is really getting into games - and she's always asking if we can break out the Monopoly board game. Frankly, while I love it, it isn't a game you can just set up and play for 10 minutes - and so I was looking for something that followed some of the rules of Monopoly, but was faster. This was it. Picked this up, and found it very straight forward to learn and play, and my daughter loves it.

I love card games, as they usually have fast setup, and you can play many, many games (usually with one or more opponents) in the time it takes to play one full board game, and this sort of game is nice when you don't know what sort of time you have, but you just want to play.

I'd recommend it
